title: The controversial origins of the Encyclopedia - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: Who was the publisher that hired Denis Diderot to adapt the English cyclopedia in 1745?
What system did Denis Diderot adapt from Francis Bacon's work to organize the encyclopedia?

options.label: B
options.text: The Three-Part System (based on memory, reason, and imagination)

multiple-choice.question: What was the title of the preliminary discourse written by Jean le Rond d'Alembert that championed independent investigative reasoning as the path to progress?
What happened to the book on anatomy written by Louis de Jaucourt that was shipped to Amsterdam to be published uncensored?

options.label: A
options.text: The book was published uncensored in Amsterdam.

options.label: D
options.text: The book was shipped to Amsterdam to be published uncensored, but it sank at sea.

multiple-choice.question: Who contributed entries to the encyclopedia, including history, elegance, and fire?

Who was the mistress of the French King who helped Denis Diderot?
In what year were the uncensored pages of the encyclopedia re-published in Russia?

title: The science of skin color - Angela Koine Flynn

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for the variation in skin color among humans?
Which type of melanin is responsible for giving skin and hair its brown color?
What is the primary function of melanin in the skin?

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the skin from damage

multiple-choice.question: Why did humans adapt to have a higher melanin production threshold in areas near the Equator?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect themselves from the cold

options.label: D
options.text: To have a more attractive skin tone

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition that humans experience when they have a vitamin D deficiency?
Why did some humans develop lighter skin as they migrated northward?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect themselves from the cold

options.label: C
options.text: To have a more attractive skin tone

options.label: D
options.text: To better absorb UV light and produce vitamin D

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the pigment that gives skin and hair its red color?
What is the role of rhodopsin in the skin?

options.label: C
options.text: To protect the skin from damage

options.label: D
options.text: To stimulate the production of melanin

multiple-choice.question: Why did humans adapt to have a darker skin tone in areas near the Equator?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect themselves from the cold

options.label: D
options.text: To have a more attractive skin tone

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of our ancestors' adaptability to their environment?

options.label: A
options.text: A wide range of skin colors

title: How to speak so that people want to listen

multiple-choice.question: Many people have the experience that when they speak, people don't listen to them.

options.label: A
options.text: People are not interested in what they have to say.

options.label: B
options.text: People are being judged and found wanting at the same time.

options.label: C
options.text: People are not using the right register when speaking.

options.label: D
options.text: People are not listening to them because of the way they speak.

multiple-choice.question: What does the word "hail" represent in the context of powerful speech?

options.label: B
options.text: A way to start a conversation.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of vocal warm-up exercise.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to end a speech.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is a key aspect of effective speech?
What is prosody in the context of speech?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a way to convey strong emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a way to convey complex ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a way to convey meaning and emphasis through various vocal qualities.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to convey meaning and emphasis.

multiple-choice.question: Why are voices with a lower pitch often associated with power and authority?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are associated with power and authority.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are more like hot chocolate.

multiple-choice.question: What is sodcasting?

options.label: A
options.text: Imposing your sound on people around you carelessly and inconsiderately.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of vocal warm-up exercise.

options.label: C
options.text: A way to get people's attention.

options.label: D
options.text: A way to end a speech.

multiple-choice.question: What are the six vocal warm-up exercises mentioned in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: Arms up, deep breath in, and sigh out.

options.label: B
options.text: Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above, including arms up, deep breath in, and sigh out, Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba, Ba, Brrrrrrrrrr, and exaggerated la, la, la, la, la, la, la, la, la, and rolling an R, and the siren (weeeaawww).

multiple-choice.question: What would the world be like if people spoke powerfully to those who were listening consciously in environments that were fit for purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: It would be a world that is noisier.

options.label: B
options.text: It would be a world that is more chaotic.

options.label: C
options.text: It would be a world that is more beautiful.

options.label: D
options.text: It would be a world that is more understanding.

multiple-choice.question: What is the idea being spread at the end of the transcript?

options.label: B
options.text: The idea of creating sound consciously and consuming sound consciously.

options.label: C
options.text: The idea of designing all our environments consciously for sound.

multiple-choice.question: What is the point being made about how we can communicate effectively?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a point about how we can get people's attention.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a point about how we can convey complex ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a point about how we can speak powerfully to people who are listening consciously in environments which are actually fit for purpose.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a point about how we can create a more conscious and effective communication environment.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following are considered "seven deadly sins of speaking"?
What are the four cornerstones of powerful speech mentioned in the transcript?
What is the purpose of prosody in speech?

options.label: D
options.text: To convey meaning and emphasis, and to get people's attention.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of prosody in speech?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a way to convey strong emotions.

options.label: B
options.text: It's a way to convey complex ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a way to convey meaning and emphasis.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to convey meaning and emphasis, and to get people's attention.

multiple-choice.question: What would the world be like if people created sound consciously and consumed sound consciously, and designed all our environments consciously for sound?

options.label: A
options.text: It would be a world that is more chaotic.

options.label: B
options.text: It would be a world that is more understanding.

options.label: C
options.text: It would be a world that is more beautiful.

options.label: D
options.text: It would be a world that is more understanding.

title: Every kid needs a champion - Rita Pierson

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary focus of the speaker's career?

options.label: C
options.text: Building relationships and connecting with students

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea that the speaker emphasizes throughout their speech?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of standardized testing in education

options.label: B
options.text: The value and importance of human connection in education

options.label: C
options.text: The role of technology in modern education

options.label: D
options.text: The need for more funding in education

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: That educators should give up on students who are difficult to teach

title: The immortal cells of Henrietta Lacks - Robin Bulleri

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of growing human cells in the lab?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for cancer

options.label: B
options.text: To test the efficacy of vaccines

options.label: C
options.text: To study the effects of viruses on the human body

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how diseases develop in the human body and test new treatments without endangering patients

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with discovering the first immortal human cell line?
What is the name of the patient from whom the HeLa cells were taken?

options.label: A
options.text: A tobacco farm worker in Virginia

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process by which normal human cells self-destruct after a certain number of divisions?
What is the primary reason why HeLa cells are able to survive for an extended period of time?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a higher number of chromosomes than normal human cells

options.label: B
options.text: They have a lower number of chromosomes than normal human cells

options.label: C
options.text: They ignore the signals that prevent the propagation of genetic errors and divide indefinitely

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary role of HeLa cells in the development of the polio vaccine?

options.label: B
options.text: To study the effects of the virus on the human body

options.label: D
options.text: To test the vaccine's efficacy in a controlled environment

multiple-choice.question: What is the enzyme that helps cancer cells evade destruction by repairing their DNA?
What is the primary reason why HeLa cells are able to travel on almost any surface?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a higher number of chromosomes than normal human cells

options.label: B
options.text: They are able to evade the process of apoptosis

options.label: C
options.text: They are highly resilient and able to survive in a variety of environments

options.label: D
options.text: They are able to replicate indefinitely

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the virus that was discovered to cause cervical cancer thanks to HeLa cells?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of viruses on the human body

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for cancer

options.label: C
options.text: To test the efficacy of vaccines

options.label: D
options.text: To understand how diseases develop in the human body and test new treatments without endangering patients

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They have 23 chromosomes, half the number of normal human cells

options.label: D
options.text: They have a variable number of chromosomes

multiple-choice.question: Who was the scientist who discovered a chemical that makes chromosomes visible?

options.label: C
options.text: A scientist working with HeLa cells

multiple-choice.question: What was the first thing to be cloned using HeLa cells?
What was the primary use of HeLa cells in the space program?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of zero gravity on human cells

options.label: B
options.text: To test the safety of space travel for humans

options.label: C
options.text: To study the effects of radiation on human cells

options.label: D
options.text: To study the effects of zero gravity on human cells

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the farm where Henrietta Lacks was born?

options.label: A
options.text: A tobacco farm in North Carolina

multiple-choice.question: Who sent samples of HeLa cells to labs all over the world?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The polio epidemic was under control

options.label: D
options.text: The polio epidemic was a minor issue

options.label: B
options.text: To study the effects of the virus on the human body

options.label: D
options.text: To test the vaccine's efficacy in a controlled environment

title: #TEDEdChat: A Math Class Makeover | Dan Meyer |

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue that the speaker, a high school math teacher, wants to address in his classroom?

options.label: A
options.text: The way math education is structured in the US, which prioritizes computation over math reasoning

options.label: B
options.text: The lack of initiative among his students

options.label: C
options.text: The difficulty of teaching math reasoning and patient problem-solving

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the result of teaching math education in the US today?

options.label: A
options.text: Students are well-prepared for math-related fields

options.label: B
options.text: Students are able to retain math reasoning skills

options.label: C
options.text: Students lack initiative, perseverance, and retention in math

options.label: D
options.text: Students are only interested in computation

multiple-choice.question: Who is quoted by the speaker as saying that the formulation of a problem is incredibly important?
What is the main difference between the way the speaker's textbook presents math problems and the way he prefers to present them?

options.label: A
options.text: The textbook presents problems with a surplus of information, while the speaker presents problems with a lack of information

options.label: B
options.text: The textbook presents problems with a lack of information, while the speaker presents problems with a surplus of information

options.label: C
options.text: The textbook presents problems that focus on computation, while the speaker presents problems that focus on math reasoning and patient problem-solving

options.label: D
options.text: The textbook presents problems that focus on math reasoning, while the speaker presents problems that focus on computation

multiple-choice.question: What tool does the speaker use to bring real-world examples into his classroom?
According to the speaker, what is the benefit of using multimedia in the classroom?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows students to work independently

options.label: B
options.text: It helps students to visualize complex concepts

options.label: C
options.text: It brings the real world into the classroom in high resolution and full color, allowing students to develop their intuition and understand how math applies to the world

options.label: D
options.text: It makes math more fun and engaging

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the speaker's students are initially hesitant to participate in math conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: They are intimidated by the complexity of the math concepts

options.label: B
options.text: They are unsure of how to approach the problems

options.label: C
options.text: They are intimidated by the formula and are afraid to ask questions

options.label: D
options.text: They are intimidated by the fact that someone else has the formula, which makes them feel that they need to have the answer before participating

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome of the speaker's method of teaching math, where he starts with a real-world example and then develops the math concept?

options.label: A
options.text: Students are able to solve complex math problems, but they don't understand the underlying concepts

options.label: B
options.text: Students are able to understand the underlying math concepts, but they are not able to apply them to real-world problems

options.label: C
options.text: Students are able to understand and apply the math concepts to real-world problems, developing their math reasoning and patient problem-solving skills

options.label: D
options.text: Students are able to work independently and don't need to ask questions

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main reason why he is less helpful to his students?

options.label: A
options.text: He wants to give them more autonomy

options.label: B
options.text: He wants to challenge them to think critically

options.label: C
options.text: He wants to buy them out of their obligation for patient problem-solving and math reasoning by providing them with too much help

options.label: D
options.text: He wants to make math more fun and engaging

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's conclusion about the state of math education in the US?

options.label: A
options.text: It is excellent and students are well-prepared for math-related fields

options.label: B
options.text: It is mediocre and students are able to get by with minimal effort

options.label: C
options.text: It is poor and students lack initiative and perseverance in math

options.label: D
options.text: People are hungry for better math curriculum and more patient problem-solvers, making it an amazing time to be a math teacher

title: Why certain wildfires are necessary - Jim Schulz

multiple-choice.question: According to anthropologists, what was the primary source of fire for early hominids?

options.label: A
options.text: Producing only one type of cone

options.label: B
options.text: Growing cones on the forest floor

options.label: C
options.text: Growing two types of cones, one of which requires high temperatures to release seeds

options.label: A
options.text: By releasing seeds in response to cold temperatures

options.label: B
options.text: By releasing seeds in response to high temperatures

options.label: C
options.text: By producing only one type of seed

options.label: A
options.text: To clear land and create a sunny area

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the forest from pests

options.label: C
options.text: To release seeds from serotinous cones and promote new forest growth

options.label: D
options.text: To destroy trees and create a barren landscape

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the risk of wildfires

options.label: B
options.text: To protect the forest from pests

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the risk of catastrophic wildfires

options.label: D
options.text: To destroy the forest and create a new landscape

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between forest fires and the birth of new forests?

options.label: A
options.text: Forest fires have no impact on the birth of new forests

options.label: B
options.text: Forest fires destroy the old forest but create a new forest by releasing seeds from serotinous cones

options.label: C
options.text: Forest fires destroy the old forest and create a barren landscape

options.label: D
options.text: Forest fires create a forest that is similar to the old one

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary benefit of forest fires to the ecosystem?

options.label: B
options.text: To reduce the risk of wildfires

options.label: C
options.text: To rejuvenate trees and maintain ecosystem health

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason for lodgepole pines growing in an umbrella-like canopy?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide shade for the forest floor

options.label: B
options.text: To release seeds in response to high temperatures

options.label: C
options.text: To grow straight and tall in competition for sunlight

options.label: D
options.text: To protect themselves from the elements

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between serotinous cones and the forest ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: Serotinous cones have no impact on the forest ecosystem

options.label: B
options.text: Serotinous cones create a barren landscape

options.label: C
options.text: Serotinous cones release seeds in response to high temperatures, allowing new forests to grow

multiple-choice.question: What is the long-term effect of a forest not burning for an extended period of time?

options.label: A
options.text: The forest will become healthier and more diverse

options.label: B
options.text: The forest will become less prone to wildfires

options.label: C
options.text: The risk of a catastrophic wildfire will increase

title: Can you solve the temple riddle? - Dennis E. Shasha

multiple-choice.question: What is the situation that the group of students find themselves in at the heart of the ancient temple?

options.label: A
options.text: They are lost and trying to find the exit.

options.label: B
options.text: They have stumbled upon a hidden treasure and are trying to escape the temple.

options.label: C
options.text: They have been cursed by the spirits of the city's King and Queen, and are trying to figure out who among them is possessed.

options.label: D
options.text: They are trying to solve a puzzle to unlock the door to the next room.

multiple-choice.question: How many students are in the group that has been cursed by the spirits of the city's King and Queen?
What is the curse that has been placed on the students?

options.label: A
options.text: The curse makes them attack each other.

options.label: B
options.text: The curse makes them lie only occasionally.

options.label: C
options.text: The curse makes them forget the way out of the temple.

multiple-choice.question: How many paths do the students have to choose from to find the exit?
What is the strategy that the group comes up with to figure out which path leads to the exit?

options.label: A
options.text: They send one student to explore each path.

options.label: B
options.text: They split into groups of four and explore two paths each.

options.label: C
options.text: They send groups of one, two, and three students to explore different paths.

options.label: D
options.text: They draw straws to decide which path to take.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not possible to send groups of four students to explore two paths each?

options.label: A
options.text: Because there are not enough students.

options.label: B
options.text: Because one group might come back split two versus two.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the students might get lost.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the paths might be too long.

multiple-choice.question: What happens if a trio returns in total agreement?

options.label: A
options.text: You know that one of the students is lying.

options.label: B
options.text: You know that none of the students are lying.

options.label: C
options.text: You know that the students are trying to trick you.

options.label: D
options.text: You know that the students are lost.

multiple-choice.question: What happens if a pair returns with conflicting answers?

options.label: A
options.text: You know that one of the students is lying.

options.label: B
options.text: You know that both students are lying.

options.label: C
options.text: You can't be sure either way.

options.label: D
options.text: You know that the students are trying to trick you.

multiple-choice.question: What is the final strategy that the group comes up with to figure out which path leads to the exit?

options.label: A
options.text: They send one student to explore each path.

options.label: B
options.text: They split into groups of four and explore two paths each.

options.label: C
options.text: They send groups of one, two, and three students to explore different paths, and then use the process of elimination to figure out which path leads to the exit.

options.label: D
options.text: They draw straws to decide which path to take.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the group at the end of the story?

options.label: A
options.text: They are trapped in the temple forever.

options.label: B
options.text: They are able to escape the temple, but two of the students are possessed by the spirits of the city's King and Queen.

options.label: C
options.text: They are able to escape the temple, and none of the students are possessed by the spirits of the city's King and Queen.

options.label: D
options.text: They are able to escape the temple, but they are not sure which students are possessed by the spirits of the city's King and Queen.

title: The most lightning-struck place on Earth - Graeme Anderson

multiple-choice.question: What was Sir Francis Drake's goal when he sailed across the Gulf of Venezuela in 1595?

options.label: A
options.text: To establish a trade route between England and the Spanish colonies

options.label: B
options.text: To overthrow a colony of Spanish settlers on the nearby Lake Maracaibo

options.label: C
options.text: To explore the nearby Lake Maracaibo for its natural resources

multiple-choice.question: What natural phenomenon foiled Sir Francis Drake's plan to overthrow the Spanish settlers on Lake Maracaibo?

options.label: C
options.text: A sudden and intense lightning storm

multiple-choice.question: What is unique about Lake Maracaibo in terms of its weather?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the driest place on the planet

options.label: B
options.text: It has the highest average temperature on the planet

options.label: C
options.text: It has the lowest average humidity on the planet

options.label: D
options.text: It is the stormiest place on the planet

multiple-choice.question: How many days of the year does thunderstorm rage above Lake Maracaibo?
What causes lightning to form in storm clouds?
How often does lightning strike the Earth on average?
What is the term used to describe the frequency of lightning flashes in a square kilometer?
What is unique about the lightning density at the equator compared to the polar regions?

options.label: A
options.text: The equator has a lower lightning density than the polar regions

options.label: B
options.text: The equator has a higher lightning density than the polar regions

options.label: C
options.text: The equator and polar regions have the same lightning density

options.label: D
options.text: The equator has a variable lightning density

multiple-choice.question: What are the main factors that contribute to the high lightning density at Lake Maracaibo?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of a nearby mountain range and a nearby lake

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of a nearby ocean and a nearby desert

options.label: C
options.text: The combination of solar energy, water vapor, and cool winds

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of a nearby volcano and a nearby forest

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the natural phenomenon of lightning at Lake Maracaibo that is used as a natural lighthouse?

title: How science fiction can help predict the future - Roey Tzezana

multiple-choice.question: What do governments, militaries, and industry leaders employ to forecast the future?
According to the transcript, one way futurists arrive at their predictions is by analyzing:
What is the main limitation of futurists' predictions, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: Unimaginable discoveries that arise which would make no sense to anyone in the present

multiple-choice.question: Who said, "Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic"?
What is one promising answer to the question of how to prepare for a future that will be as magical to us as our present would appear to someone from the 19th century?
Which author foretold the use of antidepressants in 1932 in his novel "Brave New World"?
What is the main purpose of science fiction, according to the transcript?

options.label: D
options.text: To all of the above, serving as a useful tool for thinking outside of the box

multiple-choice.question: Who said, "I'm no prophet. My job is making windows where there were once walls"?
Why are some futurists beginning to employ science fiction writers in their teams?

options.label: A
options.text: Because science fiction writers are good at predicting the future

options.label: B
options.text: Because science fiction writers are good at analyzing social movements and trends

options.label: C
options.text: Because science fiction writers can help them think outside the box and explore new possibilities

options.label: D
options.text: Because science fiction writers are good at analyzing economic data

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate responsibility of individuals, according to the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: To determine which possibilities they will work towards making a reality

title: Why are human bodies asymmetrical? - Leo Q. Wan

multiple-choice.question: What is the common association of symmetry in nature?
What is an example of asymmetry in animals?

options.label: A
options.text: A butterfly with symmetrical patterns on each wing.

options.label: B
options.text: A crab with one giant pincer claw.

options.label: C
options.text: A fish with identical fins on each side.

multiple-choice.question: What is the condition where all internal organs are flipped?
What is the role of the node in an embryo's development?

options.label: A
options.text: It pushes fluid from the right side to the left.

options.label: B
options.text: It senses the fluid flow and activates specific genes.

options.label: C
options.text: It directs cell growth and differentiation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the synchronized rotation of cilia on the node?
What property of biomolecules contributes to their asymmetric shape?
What is the result of asymmetry at the molecular level?
What is a theory that explains the origin of asymmetry in embryos?
What happens to the heart tube in an embryo as it develops?

options.label: B
options.text: It bends into a c-shape and rotates towards the right side of the body.

multiple-choice.question: What property of proteins contributes to their asymmetric shape?
What is an example of asymmetry in the human body?
What is the result of incomplete reversals of internal organs?

options.label: B
options.text: It can be fatal, especially if the heart is involved.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the property of cells that contributes to their ability to line up in a specific direction?
What is an example of asymmetry in bacterial colonies?

options.label: B
options.text: Lacy branches that curl in the same direction.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of zooming in on the basic building blocks of cells?

title: When will the next mass extinction occur? - Borths, D'Emic, and Pritchard

multiple-choice.question: Approximately what time ago did massive volcanic eruptions and an asteroid strike the Earth, causing a mass extinction event?
What term describes the sudden disappearance of lineages in the fossil record?
What is the name of the supercontinent formed when the Earth's land masses gathered together?
What is the estimated percentage of species that went extinct during the mass extinction event that occurred 252 million years ago?
What term describes the process by which the extinction of species occurs due to changes in the environment?
Approximately how long ago did the fluctuation of massive ice sheets at the poles cause changes in the environment that led to the extinction of large mammals?

options.label: D
options.text: Over the last few million years

multiple-choice.question: What term describes the process by which humans are actively changing the environment?
What is the estimated rate of extinction for many organisms today compared to the normal background rate?

options.label: D
options.text: Hundreds to thousands of times higher

multiple-choice.question: What term describes the process by which humans can prevent mass extinctions by learning from past events and reducing their impact on the environment?
What term describes the unique ability of humans to drive mass extinctions, but also to prevent them?

title: Holocaust survivor Francine Christophe shares her story

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of a bearing in a mechanical system?

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce friction and support loads

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of a type of design thinking?
What is the process of converting data into a visual format called?
What is the primary difference between a series and parallel circuit?

options.label: C
options.text: The type of connection (series vs. parallel)

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following materials is known for its high strength-to-weight ratio?
What is the process of identifying and prioritizing requirements for a product or system?
What is the purpose of a capacitor in an electrical circuit?

options.label: C
options.text: To provide a path for current flow

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of a type of engineering that deals with the design and development of software?

options.label: C
options.text: To create a product that meets customer needs
